channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Meta Did Not Violate the Law When It Bought Instagram and WhatsApp, a Judge Rules
item.description: Meta’s acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp did not illegally stifle competition in social networking, a judge found, a major win for the tech giant.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meta has defended itself by saying that it faces plenty of competition from rivals, including TikTok and YouTube, and that it benefited the nascent apps with bountiful resources.

item.title: Meta’s Victory Opens the Way for Silicon Valley to Go Deal Shopping
item.description: To avoid regulatory scrutiny, big tech companies had steered clear of buying start-ups outright. Meta’s antitrust win may change that thinking.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan, Mike Isaac and Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, in September. On Tuesday, a federal judge found Meta had not violated antitrust law by buying Instagram and WhatsApp when they were tiny start-ups.

item.title: Google Unveils Gemini 3, With Improved Coding and Search Abilities
item.description: The new artificial intelligence model is the second the company has released this year. OpenAI and Anthropic made similar updates a few months ago.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Google said the information produced by Gemini 3 was 72 percent accurate.

item.title: Self-Driving Taxis Are Catching On. Are You Ready?
item.description: With the arrival of Amazon’s Zoox robot taxi in San Francisco to compete with Waymo, autonomous services are gaining momentum. But there are pros and cons.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen, Cade Metz and Balazs Gardi
item.media:description: A Zoox driverless vehicle on a San Francisco street.

item.title: Trump Administration Gives Three Mile Island Nuclear Project $1 Billion Loan
item.description: The Pennsylvania site, shorthand for the dangers of nuclear power after a 1979 meltdown, is set for revival under a deal to power Microsoft data centers.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.media:credit: Ted Shaffrey/Associated Press
item.media:description: Constellation’s nuclear power plant, called the Crane Clean Energy Center, on Three Mile Island near Middletown, Pa. earlier this year.

item.title: Europe’s Chip Dreams Confront Business Realities
item.description: European chipmakers need TSMC’s help to grow their own semiconductor supply chain, but the chip giant’s Taiwanese suppliers find Europe a tough place to do business.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:credit: Milan Bures for The New York Times
item.media:description: TSMC is teaming up with European chipmakers to build a factory near Dresden, Germany, as Europe’s need to make its own chips has grown more pressing.

item.title: In the A.I. Race, Chinese Talent Still Drives American Research
item.description: Although some Silicon Valley executives paint China as the enemy, Chinese brains continue to play a major role in U.S. research.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Eli Tan
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: New research shows just how important Chinese engineering talent still is to Silicon Valley companies.

item.title: Driving an E.V. Across North Dakota? Thank the Standing Rock Tribe.
item.description: A tribally owned network of chargers will soon be complete, connecting reservations and bridging a gap in the Midwest.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey and Jaida Grey Eagle
item.media:credit: Jaida Grey Eagle for The New York Times

item.title: How TikTok Helped Meta Land an Antitrust Victory
item.description: Silicon Valley has increasingly pointed at rapid digital changes to blunt government efforts to rein in its power.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe and Steve Lohr
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Washington headquarters of the Federal Trade Commission, which sued Meta five years ago.

item.title: Google’s Gemini 3 Is Here: A Special Early Look
item.description: Maybe more than other model releases, this one seems to have the attention of Google’s competitors. Will it put the company at the top of the A.I. leaderboard?
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Jen Poyant, Chris Wood, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto and Diane Wong
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photos: Jeff Chiu/Associated Press

item.title: A.I. Video Is Threatening Our Ability to Trust Documentaries
item.description: A combination of technological developments and market forces is undermining the trust between viewer and filmmaker. What’s at stake is history itself.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Roadrunner: A Film About Anthony Bourdain (Movie)
The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst (TV Program)

item.title: Europe Begins Rethinking Its Crackdown on Big Tech
item.description: European policymakers are crafting changes to scale back and simplify landmark rules for A.I. and data privacy, in a shift from an aggressive regulatory period.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Edmon de Haro

item.title: We Can Now Track Individual Monarch Butterflies. It’s a Revelation.
item.description: Scientists used tiny new sensors to follow the insects on journeys that take thousands of miles to their winter colonies in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Dan Fagin and Jonathan Corum
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times

item.title: Jeff Bezos Creates A.I. Start-Up Where He Will Be Co-Chief Executive
item.description: Called Project Prometheus, the company is focusing on artificial intelligence for the engineering and manufacturing of computers, automobiles and spacecraft.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new artificial intelligence project partly financed by Jeff Bezos is entering an increasingly crowded market.

item.title: How Fraudsters Use Cryptocurrency A.T.M.s to Target Victims
item.description: The kiosks, which resemble conventional A.T.M.s and convert cash into virtual currencies, are increasingly under scrutiny as a tool for scammers.
item.dc:creator: Cameron Fozi, Chloe Rosenberg and Reeno Hashimoto
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Bitcoin A.T.M. in a convenience store in Miami. Crypto A.T.M. operators are in at least 28,000 locations, according to Treasury Department data.

item.title: The Crypto Industry’s $28 Billion in ‘Dirty Money’
item.description: As President Trump has championed crypto and the industry has gone mainstream, funds from scammers and other criminal groups have flowed onto major crypto exchanges.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany, Spencer Woodman and Sam Ellefson
item.media:credit: Karolis Strautniekas

item.title: How Seattle’s The Stranger Became a Progressive Kingmaker
item.description: Endorsements from The Stranger have become a must-have for some politicians, who know to bring snacks to their meetings with the paper’s writers.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Chona Kasinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Stranger newspaper plays a big role in Seattle’s progressive politics.

item.title: What’s a Digital Passport and How Does It Work?
item.description: Apple joined Google this week in allowing travelers to add their passports to their cellphone “wallets.” As the holiday travel season nears, here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Kena Betancur/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Using digital identification while traveling has become increasingly common. Both Apple and Google have introduced versions of digital passports, which can be used at many airports around the country.

item.title: Apple’s iPhone Pocket by Issey Miyake Is Confusing by Design
item.description: Decades after their founders connected, Apple and Issey Miyake released a collection of phone pouches that have some people baffled. They hope it will inspire creativity.
item.dc:creator: Yola Mzizi

item.title: Data Centers in Space + A.I. Policy on the Right + A Gemini History Mystery
item.description: “As you may have noticed, it is not easy to build data centers here on Earth.”
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Rachel Cohn, Whitney Jones, Jen Poyant, Chris Wood, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Marion Lozano
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Romolo Tavani/Getty Images

item.title: Almost Everything About NASA’s ESCAPADE Mission to Mars Is Unusual
item.description: The ESCAPADE mission, which launched to space on a Blue Origin rocket on Thursday, breaks the mold of how planetary science missions typically come together.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: UC Berkeley/UCLA/NASA

item.title: 5 Apps That Will Make You Love Art Galleries
item.description: Craving an art fix but don’t know where to start? These new art influencers can help newbies and players navigate openings, events and listings.
item.dc:creator: Martha Schwendener

item.title: The Luxury Electric Vehicle Is in Trouble
item.description: Sales of expensive battery-powered cars like the Ford F-150 Lightning have stalled, forcing automakers to slow production and offer more affordable vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ford Motor has stopped making its F-150 Lightning electric pickup truck, which starts at $55,000, and won’t say when or whether production will restart.

item.title: Northern Lights Are Beautiful, but for Satellites They’re Risky
item.description: At least one space launch has been put on hold, as satellite operators and rocket companies manage the effects of the current geomagnetic storm hitting Earth.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:credit: Helioviewer Project/NASA/ESA

item.title: Russian Humanoid Robot Falls on Its Face in Hyped Debut
item.description: The robot, known as AIDOL, staggered onstage during a technology showcase in Moscow. Organizers blamed the mishap on calibration and lighting issues.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Sanjana Varghese
item.media:credit: Maxim Shipenkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The first Russian anthropomorphic robot ‘AIDOL’ falls during their unveiling in Moscow, Russia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Solvay of Belgium Creates Rare Earths Deals With U.S.
item.description: The contracts are the latest sign of how Europe is lagging the United States in the race to break China’s chokehold on rare earths.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Solvay’s rare earths processing plant in La Rochelle, France. The company signed two deals to send rare earths to the United States.

item.title: At the Cybathlon, May the Best Brain-Computer Interface Win
item.description: Every four years at the Cybathlon, teams of researchers and technology “pilots” compete to see whose brain-computer interface holds the most promise.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:credit: Francesca Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Collumb training at the University of Bath.

item.title: Missing at U.N.’s Climate Meeting: American Executives
item.description: Many business leaders are skipping the annual United Nations climate summit in Belém, Brazil, or are attending events in other cities.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Fernando Llano/Associated Press
item.media:description: Officials from around the world are attending the U.N. climate summit in Belém, Brazil, this week, but U.S. government and business leaders are not among them.
